Topic.Title: M$ is pushing users and vendors to Macs and Linux

Message.Msg: "<sorry no I'm not affiliated with MS in any way> You wouldn't have to be, in order to be a shill. You need only be or work for a Microsoft contractor, or subcontractor, or subsubcontractor..." So essentially any individual who ever, in any circumstance, uses an MS based PC is a "shill"? I guess I'm guilty then, except that nowhere in my employment chain do I roll up to MS in any way. I do have exactly one laptop in my home running Win 7. All other pc's I have run Linux - and I built them myself. I own several IOS and Android devices. So yes I own and use every device, platform, or technology that I discuss. The general user base loves the iphone and ipad because they are good products - I've taken nothing from Apple in that regard. Many consumers will end up choosing less expensive devices when they are available and comparably functional. Many die-hard Apple users will remain, as there has always been a cult following who actually want to purchase the most expensive products to maintain social status. Going forward, Apple will continue to lose market share, and back-end IT shops will be more interested/aggressive in integrating Windows based devices into their MS based networks. These factors combined will drive MS device acceptance and adoption going forward.

Topic.Title: What Can Romney Not Hide

Message.Msg: >we don't care< That particular assumption is what will bite you on the rear come November. >he takes advantage of all tax breaks just like you hypocrites do and myself included< Since you were apparently too lazy to read and attempt to comprehend the entire article, let me clarify the situation for you. This was not a "legitimate" "tax break" and decidedly NOT something, (you are likely an exception to this), that honest people including myself would resort to. From the article that you were too lazy and arrogantly self assured to read thoroughly: "Like other prepackaged corporate tax shelters of that era, Marriott's Son of Boss transaction was an entirely artificial transaction, bearing no relationship to its business. Its sole purpose was to create a gigantic tax loss out of thin air without any economic risk, cost or loss -- other than the fee Marriott paid the promoter. The Son of Boss transaction was vulnerable to attack on at least two grounds. First, the transaction's promoters and consumers relied on a strained technical statutory analysis. Second, the Son of Boss deal violated the fundamental tax principle that the tax law ignores transactions unless they have a motivating business purpose and a substantial nontax economic effect. In the Marriott case, the IRS raised both arguments and won on the first interpretive issue. The Court of Claims (affirmed by the Court of Appeals) rejected Marriott's technical analysis, finding no reliable argument or authority to support it. The court therefore did not need to reach the issue of business purpose and economic substance. In subsequent decisions, involving similar transactions but other parties, the courts have sustained the second line of attack as well, finding the claimed losses to be fictitious. The complete judicial rejection of the Son of Boss tax scheme was entirely predictable. In mid-1994, for example, roughly contemporaneously with Marriott's execution of its Son of Boss trade and well before Marriott filed its return claiming the artificial loss, the highly respected Tax Section of the New York Bar Association filed a public comment with the U.S. Treasury and IRS urging rejection of the technical claims made by promoters of such schemes."

The first, was that requests for such waivers have come from a number of Republican governors. Misty water color memories: ***“You know how boys liked to go through their dad’s top drawer, just to sort of see what he has in there, maybe find an old coin he might not miss?” Mr. Romney asked the audience. Mr. Romney recalled doing just that: rummaging through his father’s drawer one day when he was in his teens or early 20s .… “I found a little paper card, a little pink card, and it said this entitles George W. Romney to a lifetime of a hamburger, a shake and French fries at McDonald’s,” Mr. Romney said. “It was signed by the hand of Ray Kroc.” …. “I saw this thing and was like, ‘This is a gold mine, Dad!’ ” “So I had it laminated,” Mr. Romney said. “My dad, as you know, would go almost every day to a McDonald’s restaurant and get either a hamburger or a fish filet sandwich. And he would present this little card, and of course, the person behind the counter would look and say, ‘Well, what is that?’ They’d never seen something like that, but he said it was never turned down.**** Also found in the drawer: -George's stash of “sister wife” pr0n, which Mitt also had laminated and keeps to this day. -Three bottles of industrial strength PentaGon brand BrainWash(tm), kept in case of having to prolong the Vietnam war throughout George's first term to guarantee jingoistic support for re-election. -The real twelve years of tax returns, not the ones cooked up for the “disclosure” stunt.
